Headline: Raising Angel/Pre-Seed | Founder, TimePe | Unifying Payments, Banking & Insurance for Bharat | Empowering Every Citizen With Secure,Transparent, Intelligent, AI-Driven Financial Access | Bharat-First Inclusive Fin-Tech
Comment:
This is painfully true, Rishabh Mariwala ‚Äî and it‚Äôs the bitter reality that few admit.

As a pre-revenue, early-stage founder from a smaller city, I‚Äôve lived the challenges firsthand: being underestimated because I didn‚Äôt graduate from IIT, IIM, or any top university, despite solving real, daily pain points of rural India, SHGs, and small merchants.

I‚Äôve faced financial frauds, systemic negligence, and multiple setbacks in the past ‚Äî yet investors often overlook grassroots-driven conviction in favor of pedigree or metro networks. Meanwhile, platforms exploit middlemen, ignore transparency, and undervalue the very communities they serve.

At TimePe, our mission isn‚Äôt just a business opportunity ‚Äî it‚Äôs personal. Every SHG interaction, every merchant onboarded, every product decision comes from lived understanding, not trend-chasing.

Conviction is the multiplier. And for founders like us who truly care about grassroots impact, it‚Äôs the only thing keeping us going through skepticism, delayed support, and broken systems. 

If this resonates with you in reality, I‚Äôd be truly delighted to connect and explore how you could be part of our long-term journey to reshape grassroots finance with TimePe.

Headline: Technology & Public Affairs Strategist | AI Governance | Institutional Advisory | Ethical & Future-Ready Systems
Comment:
Markets are not abstract spreadsheets or TAM estimates. They are lived systems shaped by human problems, values, and social contexts. When a founder enters a space without conviction guided only by market size the fragility shows up later. In downturns, markets don‚Äôt reward opportunism; they reward persistence, clarity, and an embedded understanding of the problem.

Conviction is not just ‚Äúpassion.‚Äù It‚Äôs structural alignment between a founder‚Äôs own commitments and the problem they are solving. That alignment produces sharper strategic insight, a more authentic narrative for customers and investors, and a resilient culture that doesn‚Äôt collapse under pressure.

Large markets matter. But they cannot substitute for the authenticity and depth that conviction provides. When cycles turn hard, what carries companies forward is not just the size of the opportunity, but whether the founder‚Äôs struggle is inseparable from the problem itself.
